I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During  the  2006  Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested a technical assistance (TA) from the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) to help the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) in promoting a 
resource-efficient society. The TA is included in the country program for 2007.1 The Fact-
Finding Mission fielded in March 2007 reached an understanding with the Government on the 
impact and outcome, methodology and key activities, scope, cost estimates, financing plan, and 
implementation  arrangements  of  the  TA.  The  TA  design  and  monitoring  framework  is  in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The sustained high economic growth rate of 9% over the past 30 years in the PRC has 
lifted 450 million people out of absolute poverty. Its economy now ranks fourth in the world, with 
a large demand for commodities (agricultural and raw materials), water, and energy. The high 
domestic  savings  rate  has  enabled  large  investments  to  increase  domestic  capacity  and 
infrastructure services, but imports have risen gradually to meet the demand. With further 
increases in incomes, the demand for energy and items that consume much energy like steel, 
cement, copper, aluminum, fertilizers, chemicals, etc., is expected to continue rising and exert 
considerable  pressure  on  natural  resources  and  the  environment.  Urbanization  and  the 
increased use of passenger cars also contribute to increased per capita energy consumption.  
 
3.  The Government’s “Guidelines of the 11th Five-Year Plan for National Economic and 
Social Development” (11FYP Guidelines) recognizes the phenomenal economic development 
during the 10FYP but also identifies some emerging binding constraints. Farmland, fresh water, 
energy, and important mineral resources are relatively insufficient; the ecology is vulnerable; the 
structure of the economy does not adequately support efficient resource utilization; and about          
9  million  new  jobs  have  to  be  created  annually.  The  capacity  for  scientific  research  and 
technological  innovation  needed  to  increase  productivity  is  still  limited.  The  Government 
recognizes the need for optimal use of its limited resources and aims to achieve high economic 
growth in a sustainable manner in the 11FYP.  
 
4.  The PRC quadrupled its per capita gross domestic product (GDP) while only doubling 
energy consumption during the 20 years from 1980 to 2000. To achieve a similar improvement 
and address some of the developmental constraints, the 11FYP, 2006–2010 has obligatory 
targets.  These  include  (i)  a  20%  reduction  in  energy  consumption  per  unit  of  GDP;                        
(ii) a 10% reduction in the total emission of major pollutants, namely, sulfur dioxide that is linked 
to the use of coal, and chemical oxygen demand that is linked to industrial effluents; and                    
(iii) a 30% reduction of water consumption per unit of industrial value added. It also anticipates 
the utilization of industrial solid waste to increase from 55.8% to 60%. Achieving these targets is 
a  serious  challenge  requiring  a  focused  approach,  particularly  toward  energy  conservation               
(to reduce pollution) and energy efficiency. 
 
5.  The Government has issued other decrees and plans that support the 11FYP guidelines. 
The Renewable Energy Law became effective on 1 January 2006 and related implementing 
decrees have been issued; these encourage the use of domestically available natural resources 
that have low environmental impact. NDRC issued the China Medium- and Long-Term Energy 
Conservation Plan that identifies 10 key areas where to reduce energy consumption. The State 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 23 February 2007.

2   
Council also issued in August 2006 a decree to enhance energy conservation. The 11FYP 
guidelines, which target the reduction of energy consumption, have been disaggregated and 
communicated to provincial governments, and the Top-1,000 Program launched in April 2006 
requires  the  industrial enterprises that  account  for  about  33%  energy  use  to prepare  and 
implement energy conservation measures.2 
 
6.  A  sound  energy  conservation  evaluation  system  (ECES)  is  critical  for  success  in 
realizing the full potential of conservation. Traditionally, energy has been measured for billing 
and technical purposes only, with aggregation done mostly for planning purposes. In most 
countries, the most common and convenient form of energy—electricity—is billed after it has 
been consumed, a fact that does not promote practices to conserve. The new policies and 
targets for energy conservation add another dimension—an account of the output derived from 
energy  use  (goods  or  service).  There  is  no  well-recognized  system  for  measuring  and 
evaluating  energy  conservation.  Leading  energy  research  institutes have  estimated  energy 
savings in an economy over a period of time on the basis of broad assumptions. For example, 
the International Energy Agency estimates that the world energy use in 1998—25 years after 
the first oil shock of 1973—would have been 49% higher without the savings realized; similarly, 
the PRC would have consumed twice as much energy in 2000 compared to 1980 had energy 
intensity remained the same. Lack of disaggregated information makes it difficult to prepare new 
programs to replicate these achievements. 
 
7.  There is an urgent need to develop a suitable ECES that is robust enough to hold 
entities accountable, as against a verification-less system that entities use voluntarily and do not 
expect to be contested. The ECES should assist in planning energy reduction programs and 
monitoring  implementation  progress,  as  against  ex  post  facto  reporting.  Government 
departments,  public  institutions  (education,  health,  transport),  enterprises  (commercial, 
industrial) and even nongovernment organizations will need to report achievement of energy 
reduction targets, i.e., a comparison of energy used per unit of output in 2006 and 2010. To be 
able to do so equitably, the ECES has to specify boundaries for all types of entities; it must be 
fairly simple, user-friendly, and low cost to implement because of the limited learning time 
available. 
 
8.  Although a measurement and verification system for energy conservation is not readily 
available, it is possible to use features of comparable systems recently developed to account for 
greenhouse gas (GHG) emission, which is closely linked to energy use. The United Nations 
Framework  Convention  on  Climate  Change  (UNFCCC)—which  came  into  force  on                        
21 March 1994 through an international treaty—has issued guidelines for the preparation of 
GHG  inventories  by  developed  countries.  The  International  Standards  Organization—the 
Switzerland-based nongovernment organization that is a network of the national standards 
institutes of 157 countries, including the Standardization Administration of China, PRC—has 
issued standards for quantifying and reporting GHGs at the organization level (14064-1:2006), 
at project level (14064-2:2006), and for their validation and verification (14064-3:2006). Like a 
financial accounting system, the GHG accounting system is designed to present a faithful, true, 
and fair account of a company’s GHG emissions. The GHG Protocol also has calculation tools 
for various industries and simple spreadsheet models with energy indices that are relevant for 
the ECES. Adoption of a framework that is internationally recognized will strengthen the ECES 
and make it easier to migrate in the future to GHG accounting and reporting.  
                                                 
2  The top 1,000 enterprises consumed an aggregated 0.6 billion tons of coal equivalent in 2004, about 47% of the 
total energy consumption for the industry sector.

3
9.  The Government has established an interministry steering committee, led by NDRC, to 
enforce initiatives to develop a resource-efficient society.3 To be effective within the short time 
available,  it  requires  (i)  a  network  of  appropriate  institutions  that  can  contribute  to  the 
assessment  and  evaluation  of  resource  conservation;  (ii)  building  the  capacity  of  relevant 
institutions;  and  (iii)  specific  technical  means  and  tools  like  a  consolidated  resource 
conservation  evaluation  system  (RCES)  that  can  measure,  verify,  and  report  resource 
conservation  measures.  However,  it  recognizes  that  a  phased  approach  is  essential  in 
developing  the  RCES.  Considering  energy  as  a  high-priority  resource,  an  ECES  will  be 
developed and pilot-tested first, then expanded and replicated to include water and other raw 
materials in a consolidated RCES. The Government proposes to take the lead and demonstrate 
energy conservation in selected central Government office buildings. It will also seek highly 
energy-intensive  enterprises  (like  iron  and  steel,  and  cement  factories)  to  implement  pilot 
energy conservation projects that can be replicated and scaled up. The demonstration and pilot 
projects will provide directions for incentives (favorable tax and rebates) for promoting energy 
conservation.  
 
10.  ADB launched the Energy Efficiency Initiative (EEI) in mid-2005 for decreasing the rate 
of climate change through increased use of sustainable energy forms. A significant outcome of 
the EEI would be decreased energy intensity in industries, commercial buildings, municipalities, 
and the agriculture and transport sectors. Support to the PRC for developing the ECES and 
related capacity building will be within the EEI. Energy conservation and energy efficiency 
improvements are key sector priorities in the country partnership strategy that is being finalized. 
ADB  is  actively  engaged  in  Guangdong,  one  of  the  provinces  with  the  highest  energy 
consumption, to develop an innovative energy efficiency project. The TA will complement the 
ongoing ADB interventions.     
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The impact of the TA will be more efficient use of resources, i.e., raw materials, water, 
and  energy.  Its  outcome  will  be  enhanced  capacity  to  measure  and  evaluate  energy 
conservation and reduction in energy used per unit of GDP. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The outputs of the TA will be (i) an ECES and benchmark standards recommended for 
highly energy-intensive enterprises and central Government office buildings; (ii) an investment 
plan for two pilot projects for demonstrating best practices cases for energy conservation;                        
(iii) recommendations on the appropriate institutional setup for assessing and evaluating energy 
conservation;  and  (iv)  a  capacity-building  package,  including  training  modules,  information 
brochures, training and communication programs, and an awareness campaign. 
 
13.  Experts from the Government Offices Administration of the State Council of the PRC, the 
Standardization  Administration  of  China,  the  Energy  Research  Institute,  and  energy 
conservation institutes will be consulted to understand current practices and identify pragmatic 
options for monitoring energy conservation. Suitable criteria will be determined for selecting 
                                                 
3 The scope of the NDRC-led committee includes conservation of raw materials for industrial production, water, and 
energy.

4   
suitable government agencies and enterprise for the preparation of the demonstration and pilot 
projects, which will be endorsed by the Government.  
 
14.  The consultant will examine international best practices and methods that can be used in 
developing the ECES, summarize the features, and make recommendations. The essential and 
desirable features of the ECES will be listed at an early stage and consensus will be built on 
them.  The  pilot  projects  will  target  selected  central  Government  office  buildings  and  an 
enterprise that is included in the Top-1,000 Program (para. 5). When a preliminary structure and 
outline  of  the  ECES  is  available,  consultants  will  use  the  information  flow  from  the 
demonstration and pilot projects to further refine and develop the ECES. Suitable documents 
and  instruction  manuals  will  be  developed  to  enable  rapid  countrywide  deployment  of  the 
information system; a knowledge dissemination program will be implemented.  
 
15.  Many international agencies and institutions, such as (i) Energy Foundation through the 
China Sustainable Energy Program, (ii) European Union China: Energy and Environmental 
Program, and (iii) French Global Environment Facility (EFEM), have launched complementary 
projects to support the 20% reduction in energy consumption per unit of GDP. These programs 
aim to address some components of the ECES. The consultants will review and assess the 
information, data, and output of these relevant studies and programs, and capture them in 
preparing the ECES and in drafting relevant recommendations.   
 
16.  The major assumptions in relation to the successful implementation of the TA include              
(i) continued emphasis on energy conservation, (ii) readiness of the Government to establish a 
transparent and effective information system, (iii) significant participation by counterpart staff; 
(iv)  adequate  and  timely  provision  of  data,  and  (v)  active  participation  in  the  consultation 
workshops and seminars. Since the ECES will be an innovation, the risk is that it may take 
considerable time and effort to arrive at a consensus on its design, and if it requires new 
procedures to capture data, a longer time will be needed to train the field staff. The Government 
is fully committed to resource conservation and NDRC has been closely involved in developing 
the required policies and guidelines. Close coordination among the consultants, executing and 
implementing agencies, and ADB will be maintained during the implementation of the TA to 
ensure  that  the  proposed  ECES  can  take  most  of  its  inputs  from  the  existing  system  for 
gathering energy-related information.4 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The total cost of the TA will be $550,000 equivalent, of which ADB will finance $400,000 
on a grant basis through the TA funding program. The Government will finance the remaining 
$150,000 equivalent through in-kind contribution, including office accommodation and facilities, 
counterpart staff, and data and other information needed for the TA. The counterpart in-kind 
contribution will be provided by NDRC or its assigned agency. The cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  The Department of Resource Conservation and Environmental Protection of NDRC will 
be the Executing Agency (EA) for the TA. The China Standards Certification Center will be the 
implementing agency (IA) responsible for day-to-day implementation of the TA activities. 
 
                                                 
4 A similar GHG protocol is being considered by NDRC to quantify, measure, and report entity-level emissions.

5
19.  The EA will establish a counterpart team with representatives from Government Offices 
Administration of the State Council of the PRC, the Standardization Administration of China, the 
Energy Research Institute, and other relevant energy conservation institutes. The counterpart 
team will interact closely with the consultants during implementation of the TA. The EA will also 
submit regular reports of the progress of implementation to the counterpart team and seek their 
guidance as required. The EA will provide interpreters and office space equipped with suitable 
office facilities in Beijing. Some office equipment to be financed under the TA will be procured 
by the international consultants in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended from time to time) and handed over to the EA upon completion of the TA. 
 
20.  ADB will engage an international consulting firm with experience in implementing similar 
energy efficiency measurement systems, following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). ADB will request a simplified technical proposal and 
consultants will be recruited using the quality- and cost-based selection method with quality-cost 
ratio of 80:20. An estimated total of 35 person-months of consulting services will be required,            
5  person-months  international  and  30  person-months  national.  The  following  international 
consultants  will  be  required  (person-months  in  parentheses)  (i)  resource  economist  and 
resource conservation specialist (2.5), (ii) energy conservation standards specialist (1.5), and   
(iii) institutional and public information specialist (1). The following national consultants will be 
required  (person-months  in  parentheses)  (i)  three  resource  economist  and  resource 
conservation specialists (4 each); (ii) two energy conservation standards specialists (4 each);            
(ii) an institutional and public information specialist (4); (iv) a building energy conservation 
specialist (3); and (v) an enterprise energy conservation specialist (3). The outline terms of 
reference for consultants are given in Appendix 3. 
 
21.  The TA will be implemented over 10 months beginning August 2007, with an expected 
completion  date  of  end-May  2008.  The  consultants  will  submit  an  inception  report  within             
4 weeks, a midterm report within 16 weeks, a draft final report within 26 weeks, and the final 
report within 36 weeks of field mobilization. Information on the progress of implementation and 
on TA outputs will be disseminated through the TA information dissemination and awareness 
program. The outcome of the TA will be subject to evaluation by both ADB and the Government 
in accordance with their respective evaluation policies and requirements.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Promoting Resource Conservation and 
Energy Efficiency, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  be  implemented  in  consultation  with  relevant 
stakeholders,  including  the  National  Development  and  Reforms  Commission  (NDRC),  China 
Standards Certification Center (CSC), Energy Research Institute, energy conservation community, 
and other development agencies. The international consultants (5 person-months) will coordinate 
their work with the national consultants (30 person-months). The international consultants will have 
expertise  in  (i)  resource  economics  and  resource  conservation,  (ii)  standards  for  energy 
conservation, and (iii) institutional and public information systems. The national consultants will 
have expertise in the same areas, and also in energy conservation in government buildings and 
enterprises  (two  experts).  The  international  resource  economist  and  resource  conservation 
specialist will be the team leader and will coordinate the activities of the consultant team.     
 
A.  International Consultants  
 
2.  Resource Economist and Resource Conservation Specialist/Team Leader (2.5 person-
months). The expert will undertake the following activities.  
 
(i)  Review existing resource conservation laws, and related regulations and standards 
for resource conservation. 
(ii)  Review all ongoing and completed relevant studies such as, but not limited to,                
(a)  Energy  Foundation  through  the  China  Sustainable  Energy  Program;                    
(b) European Union China: Energy and Environmental Program; and (c) French 
Global Environment Facility (EFEM), to ensure that relevant studies and projects are 
fully considered during TA implementation. 
(iii)  Review the 11th Five-Year Plan targets and disaggregated targets for the sectors 
and provinces for resource and energy conservation. 
(iv)  Identify the gaps, if any, between the targets and the resource conservation laws, 
existing regulations, and codes or standards. Propose an appropriate road map— 
package of market-oriented incentives, standards, and regulations to promote, and 
monitor resource conservation. 
(v)  Develop  an  overall  framework  and  a  modular  design  for  a  suitable  resource 
conservation management system (RCES). Within the framework, identify the fit for 
the various modules/elements—energy, water, raw material, etc. 
(vi)  Expand  and  elaborate  on  the  detailed  structure  of  an  energy  conservation 
evaluation  system  (ECES)  that  can  capture  compliance  with  the  energy 
conservation standards and benchmark efficiency levels in its various subsectors. 
(vii)  In  detailed  consultation  with  NDRC,  CSC,  and  key  stakeholders,  develop 
benchmark standards and criteria for selecting pilot central Government buildings 
and highly energy-intensive industrial enterprises to promote energy conservation. 
(viii)  In conjunction with other team members, prepare detailed prefeasibility reports—
scope,  costs,  financing,  financial  viability,  etc.—for  selected  pilot  projects  to 
conserve energy in government buildings and industrial enterprises. 
(ix)  Illustrate and demonstrate the use of ECES in the pilot projects and prepare detailed 
documentation. 
(x)  Identify and recommend an appropriate institutional setup to monitor, and report 
energy conservation.

3.  Energy  Conservation  Standards  Specialist  (1.5  person-months).  The  specialist  will 
support the team leader in relevant tasks and will undertake the following specific tasks.  
 
(i)  Review the existing energy conservation standards in the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC), and compare the average energy efficiency standards in various subsectors—
key  energy-consuming  industries  (steel,  cement,  etc.),  offices,  residences,  and 
commercial buildings, appliances, etc. Identify gaps, if any, between them and current 
best practices and methods. 
(ii)  Assist  the  team  leader  in  designing  the  ECES  and  provide  applicable  energy 
efficiency levels and standards. 
(iii)  Assist the team leader in developing benchmark standards and criteria for selecting 
pilot  Government  buildings  and  industrial  enterprises  for  promoting  energy 
conservation. 
(iv)  Develop a road map for strengthening relevant PRC standards in line with current 
best international standards. 
 
4.  Institutional and Public Information Specialist (1 person-month). The specialist will be 
responsible  for  developing  a  suite  of  information  packages  to  disseminate  information  to 
government agencies, industries, commercial building operators, and the general public and to 
promote an energy conservation society. The TA’s tasks will be undertaken in a consultative 
manner with extensive discussions with relevant stakeholders. The specialist will aim to bring 
together and ensure participation of key stakeholders in TA activities. In particular, the specialist 
will undertake the following tasks.  
 
(i)  Organize  national  and  international  workshops  and  seminars  to  progressively 
discuss and disseminate TA findings and recommendations. 
(ii)  In collaboration with the other consultants on the team, develop an information 
brochure on various aspects and elements of energy conservation in society. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
5.  A  team  of  national  consultants  with  similar  expertise  will  supplement  and  support  the 
international consultants. The national consultants team will comprise (i) three resource economist 
and  resource  conservation  specialists  (4  person-months  each),  (ii)  two  energy  conservation 
standards specialists (4 person-months each), (iii) an institutional and public information specialist 
(4 person-month), (iv) a building energy conservation specialist (3 person-months), and (v) an 
enterprise energy conservation specialist (3 person-months). The national consultants will have 
extensive knowledge of resource and energy conservation issues in the PRC and will assist the 
international consultants to quickly become familiar with their tasks by reviewing relevant reports, 
analytical data, policies, regulations, and translating relevant documents into English. The building 
energy  conservation  specialist  and  the  enterprise  energy  conservation  specialist  will  provide 
relevant technical expertise to the team in designing the pilot/demonstration project.
